abstract.text: An object containing the location and unique identifier of an Apple App Store storefront.

inlineContent.text: In-app products you create through App Store Connect are available for sale in every region with an App Store. You can use the storefront information to determine the customer’s region, and offer in-app products suitable for that region. StoreKit exposes
storefront information as a read-only property in
You must maintain your own list of product identifiers and the storefronts in which you want to make them available.

Don’t save the storefront information with your customer information; storefront information can change at any time. Always get the storefront identifier immediately before you display product information or availability to the customer in your app. Storefront information may not be used to develop or enhance a customer profile, or track customers for advertising or marketing purposes.

content.text: Show Products Based on the Current Storefront

inlineContent.text: The following example function
returns
if your product isn’t suitable for the given storefront. You must create your own list of products available by storefront, referred to as
below:

code: func shouldShow(_ productIdentifier: String, in storefront: SKStorefront) -> Bool {
// myProducts is a dictionary representing your own metadata for products,

inlineContent.text: The following code listing requests information for products that you wish to display based on the device’s storefront. It uses the
function defined above.

inlineContent.text: The current storefront can change at any time, including during a transaction. The following code listing determines whether the transaction should continue in the updated storefront. Your delegate’s
method must return quickly, before the call times out. The
function is defined in

code: SKPaymentQueue.default().delegate = self  // Set your object as the SKPaymentQueue delegate.

inlineContent.text: If the product isn’t available in the updated storefront, the transaction fails with the error
. Handle this error in your
method by displaying an alert to let the customer know why the app can’t complete the transaction, as shown below:

code: if let transactionError = transaction.error as NSError?,

content.text: Change the App Store Country or Region in the Sandbox Environment

inlineContent.text: When you change the App Store Country or Region in App Store Connect for a Sandbox Apple ID, it changes the storefront in your app. Change the region to test in-app purchases for different regions in your app. For more information about changing the App Store Country or Region in App Store Connect, see
To successfully activate a storefront after you change the region in App Store Connect, sign out of the Sandbox Apple ID account on the device and sign back in.

abstract.text: Support In-App Purchases and interactions with the App Store.
Error code indicating that the requested product is not available in the store.
A queue of payment transactions for the App Store to process.
Asks the delegate whether to continue the transaction if the device’s App Store storefront changes during a transaction.
Tells an observer that one or more transactions have been updated.
Tells the observer that the storefront for the payment queue has changed.
An object containing the location and unique identifier of an Apple App Store storefront.

doc://com.apple.storekit/documentation/S.title: Show Products Based on the Current Storefront

abstract.text: The three-letter code representing the country or region associated with the App Store storefront.
A value defined by Apple that uniquely identifies an App Store storefront.
The region and unique identifier of the App Store storefront for the device.
Test your implementation of In-App Purchases using real product information and server-to-server transactions in the sandbox environment.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
